questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following are functions of oxytocin?
questions.explanation:
Oxytocin plays a role in milk ejection. It also helps in initiation or facilitation of labour by 
stimulating the contraction of uterine smooth muscles. It stimulates postpartum milk let-down in response to suckling. Prolactin is the hormone responsible for milk production. 84 
Sold by @itachibot Osmoregulation is mediated by hormones such as ADH, aldosterone, etc.

questions.question: Question 2: Where are arginine vasopressin (AVP) and oxytocin stored?
questions.explanation:
AVP/Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and oxytocin are stored in Herring bodies at the axon terminals 
of the posterior pituitary. They are synthesized by two types of magnocellular neurons in the 
supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements is true?

options.a: AVP binds to V1 receptors on the serosal surface of renal tubular cells
options.b: AVP binds to V1 receptors on the luminal surface of renal tubular cells
options.c: AVP binds to V2 receptors on the serosal surface of renal tubular cells
options.d: AVP binds to V2 receptors on the luminal surface of renal tubular cells

questions.explanation:
AVP binds to V2 receptors on the serosal surface (also called basolateral surface) of renal tubular 
cells. This interaction activates adenylyl cyclase and leads to the insertion of water channels called 
aquaporin 2 on the luminal surface of the cell.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements about ADH is incorrect?

options.a: It increases aquaporin expression on apical membrane
options.b: It increases urine concentration and decreases urine flow
options.d: Its secretion occurs when plasma osmolality is low

questions.explanation:
ADH secretion reduces when the plasma osmolality becomes low. ADH causes water reabsorption 
and dilutes the plasma, thereby causing a reduction in plasma osmolality. The antidiuretic effect of ADH is mediated via a G protein-coupled V2 receptor that increases 
intracellular cyclic AMP, thereby inducing translocation of aquaporin 2 (AQP 2) water channels 
into the apical membrane. During and after surgery, surgical stress results in the release of ADH.

questions.question: Question 5: A mutation in the gene for aquaporin channel leads to which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
A mutation in the gene for aquaporin 2 channel leads to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. The antidiuretic hormone (ADH) binds to V2 receptors in the late distal tubules, collecting 
tubules, and collecting ducts, and stimulates the movement of an intracellular protein, called 
aquaporin-2 (AQP-2), to the luminal side of the cell membranes. Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a condition in which there is the absence of or poor response to 
anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). This results in reduced permeability of the distal tubules and 
collecting ducts to water. This furthermore leads the kidneys to excrete large amounts of dilute 
urine that clinically manifests as polyuria and polydipsia. DI can be of four types : Note: Lithium - used to treat bipolar disorder, can cause acquired diabetes insipidus by decreasing 
the expression of the AQP2 gene. 85 
Sold by @itachibot Option A : Liddle’s syndrome is due to an inherited gain of function mutation of genes regulating 
the Na channel in collecting duct ENaC, characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and 
metabolic alkalosis. Option C : Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder due to mutation in CFTR gene that 
serves as a channel in the luminal plasma membranes of epithelial cells and regulates volume and 
composition of secretions in exocrine glands. Option D : Bartter syndrome is due to loss-of-function mutations of transporters and ion channels 
in thick ascending loop of henle, most commonly, Na-K-2Cl transporter. Types

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following conditions would you not expect to see in a patient with Wolfram 
syndrome?
questions.explanation: Diabetes insipidus is a clinical component of Wolfram syndrome, and not SIADH. Characteristics of Wolfram syndrome include: • Diabetes insipidus • Diabetes mellitus • Optic atrophy • Sensorineural deafness (Mnemonic DIDMOAD) Wolfram syndrome is caused by mutations of the WFS1 gene.

questions.question: Question 7: All of the following statements about diabetes insipidus are true, except:
questions.explanation:
In diabetes insipidus, hypernatremia is observed in the affected patient. 86 
Sold by @itachibot Low levels of vasopressin lead to the excretion of a large amount of diluted urine. This loss of 
water from the body leads to hypernatremia.

questions.question:
Question 8: A man presented with frequent urination and increased thirst. Investigations revealed low 
urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. MRI brain was done, which revealed the 
absence of posterior pituitary bright spot. Which of the following conditions is least likely to 
lead to this presentation? 81 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and the absence of a posterior pituitary bright spot on MRI are suggestive of 
central diabetes insipidus. Multiple sclerosis causes primary polydipsia, not central DI. Central DI is caused by a primary deficiency in AVP secretion which usually results from agenesis 
or irreversible destruction of the posterior pituitary. It can be differentiated from primary 
polydipsia with the help of an MRI brain. The MRI given below shows the posterior pituitary bright spot. The arrow points at the posterior 
pituitary and the arrowhead at the anterior pituitary. 87 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient presented with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. Investigations revealed 
24-hour urine output of Ž litres and low urinary osmolality. ADH assay was performed and 
the recorded values were reported as 1.5 pg/ml. Which of the following drugs would not cause 
this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Isoniazid is not a potential 
cause of this condition. Nephrogenic DI develops due to resistance to the antidiuretic action of AVP. A 24-hour urine 
volume >3 liters is suggestive of polyuria. An ADH value >1 pg/ml is suggestive of 
nephrogenic DI.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient presents with polyuria and increased thirst. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia. 
What could be the cause of polyuria in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Metabolic derangements like hypercalcemia and hypokalemia lead to the production of large 
amounts of dilute urine by causing nephrogenic DI. Options C & D: Primary polydipsia is of three types: • Dipsogenic – Due to inappropriate thirst. • Iatrogenic – Due to an increase in fluid intake due to its presumed health benefits. • Psychogenic – Due to psychosis or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 29-year-old lady presented with polydipsia and polyuria. Her symptoms started soon after a 
road traffic accident ‘ months ago. Her blood pressure was recorded at 120/80 mmHg with 
no postural drop. The daily urinary output was reported to be between ‘-8 liters. Clinical 
investigation results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis for the given clinical scenario would be psychogenic polydipsia. The normal range of urine osmolality is 500-850 mOsm/L and that of plasma osmolality is 
280-295 mOsm/L. Hence in the given scenario, both urine and plasma osmolality are low, along 
with hyponatremia suggestive of psychogenic polydipsia. Condition

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient presented with polyuria and polydipsia. She has been on lithium therapy for ‘ years 
for bipolar disorder. Investigations revealed low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. 
Which of the following drugs can be used for the treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of lithium-induced nephrogenic DI. Among the given options 
thiazide diuretics is the best suited answer. Thiazides reduce the kidney’s ability to excrete free water by increasing proximal tubular water 
reabsorption (secondary to volume contraction) and block the ability of DCT to form dilute 
urine. This effect results in an increase in urine osmolality. Treatment of diabetes insipidus: • Central and gestational diabetes insipidus: • Desmopressin an ADH analog • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus: • Adequate water intake along with a low sodium diet • Thiazide diuretics • Potassium-sparing diuretics (triamterene and amiloride): Amiloride is the drug of choice for 
lithium-induced DI • Prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor (indomethacin) 89 
Sold by @itachibot • Psychogenic diabetes insipidus: • Behavioral therapy to reduce fluid consumption

questions.question:
Question 14: Polyuria characterized by low fixed specific gravity of urine is seen in which of the following 
conditions?
questions.explanation:
Fixed specific gravity, in which values remain 1.010 regardless of fluid intake, occurs in chronic 
glomerulonephritis with severe renal damage. In chronic kidney disease, as renal function deteriorates, polyuria can be seen due to the 
impairment of the kidney's ability to concentrate urine. In diabetes insipidus, although specific gravity is low it is not fixed. Potomania (beer potomania/beer drinker's potomania/ beer drinker's hyponatremia) is a specific 
hypo-osmolality syndrome related to massive consumption of beer.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. 24-hour urine volume was 
measured and recorded to be Ž liters. The urine osmolarity was 2‘0 mOsm/L. ADH assay was 
performed and the recorded values were reported as 0.8 pg/ml. An MRI of the brain was 83 
Sold by @itachibot performed and T1 weighted indicated the absence of the bright spot. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The features of frequent urination, nocturia, with polyuria(>3L/day), low urine 
osmolarity(<280 mosm/L), low plasma ADH levels and MRI showing absent pituitary bright 
spot is suggestive of Pituitary Diabetes Insipidus. Diabetes Insipidus(DI) : Treatment: • For Central DI, synthetic analog of ADH Desmopressin(DDAVP) is used. • For Nephrogenic DI, a low sodium diet with thiazide diuretic and/or amiloride and prostaglandin 
synthesis inhibitor is used. 90 
Sold by @itachibot • For primary polydipsia, there are no effective drugs used but for Iatrogenic type patient 
education is helpful. Other options: Option A: In nephrogenic DI, there is polyuria, low urine osmolarity but the ADH levels will be 
>1pg/mL. Option B: In primary polydipsia, there is polyuria, low urine osmolarity, ADH levels will be 
<1pg/mL but a pituitary bright spot present. Option D: In solute loss (mannitol or hypertonic saline infusion), urine osmolality is >300
